awd_titl_txt: FSML:  Enhancing Novel Research and Education Capacity in Central Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
This project transforms two uniquely located comparative field sites to support a diverse array of research, education, and capacity building efforts in Africa's Congo Basin ((https://www.cbi.ucla.edu/field-stations/).  The project provides basic scientific instrumentation and modest facilities upgrades that will permit longer stays, and sustainability measures at two biological field stations in Cameroon: 1) the Somalomo station in secondary forest at the border of the Dja Biosphere Reserve, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and 2) the Bouamir station, located in mature rainforest at the center of the reserve.  The project supports research in a region where species loss, deforestation, emerging diseases, and natural resource extraction are having global impacts.  It increases critical local scientific capacity in the region by pairing American scientists with African researchers.  The two field sites also hire and train naturalists from indigenous Baka villages, facilitating the translation of traditional knowledge and providing meaningful employment to this marginalized group.  Ultimately, the project will increase the capacity for American-led scientific research on topics such as emerging infectious diseases food and water security and ecosystem function.

Having one station located at the human forest interface and a second within a mature tropical rainforest offers researchers an unparalleled opportunity to conduct comparative work in a very understudied region. The sites support research and education on a variety of topics, including human and animal disease, food and water security, anthropology, geology, and environmental sciences.  This project increases scientific capacity at the sites through: (1) Improved scientific equipment by creating a networked system of basic sensors (e.g., weather stations, temperature loggers, and other biomonitoring equipment) that will report on ecological and environmental variables. (2) Facilities upgrades including adding plumbing and other basic conveniences. (3) Increased functionality and sustainability at the sites by providing solar-based electricity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Bouamir and Somalomo Research Stations are located in the dense tropical rainforest of the Congo Basin, in the middle of the 526,000-hectare Dja Faunal Reserve in southern Cameroon.  They are two of the very few biological field stations in the rainforests of Central Africa, providing a critical platform for conducting research on this vast and under-studied ecosystem, which harbors many billions of tons of carbon, and tens of thousands of species, many of which are found nowhere else on Earth.  The stations host researchers from around the world who study the tropical rainforest and all of the organisms that inhabit it, ranging from mushrooms to ants to elephants.

This project improved the infrastructure at both biological field stations, making a significant contribution to advancing ecological research in the Congo Basin by enabling consistent open access to environmental data, improving electrical provision, and increasing research capacity on site. The stations can now capture and transmit temperature, precipitation, solar radiation, humidity, wind speed and direction, and barometric pressure, among other metrics, and the data is available to anyone who creates a free login.

The project also installed solar systems in both sites to provide basic electrical access, and the added satellite internet to improve communications, safety and increase research capacity. For example, the new solar and battery installation allowed a NASA-funded team to collect drone-mounted LiDAR data from the study site, which was only possible because the new solar array generates sufficient power to charge and re-charge the energy-intensive drone batteries. The internet connectivity has also been a huge boon to research on site, particularly for graduate students who can now connect in real time with their offsite professors for advice and guidance. For example, an NSF-funded team from the California Academy of Sciences has been able to rely on the internet service to connect the PI in California with Cameroonian masters’ students on site. This has allowed bi-monthly sample and data collection by local students for collaborative use with the American PI, which has resulted in a far greater amount of data collection than would have been possible otherwise.  Other improvements include improving access to water at both sites and improving the buildings.

In summary, the project has made significant contributions to advancing ecological research in the Congo Basin by enabling consistent open access to environmental data, improving electrical provision, and increasing research capacity on site. These outcomes have far-reaching implications for the scientific community and the general public alike.  Scientists who are interested in conducting research at Somalomo or Bouamir Biological Field Stations are encouraged to visit this website to learn more: https://www.cbi.ucla.edu/field-stations
